Create defensible space by removing brush and other flammable materials away from the area directly next to your home. This will help prevent wildfires from reaching your door. Find information on how to create defensible space here:

https://www.readyforwildfire.org/prepare-for-wildfire/get-ready/defensible-space/

Be sure to have an emergency evacuation kit ready and accessible. Wildfires can start and spread in a moment‚Äôs notice, so being able to evacuate quickly is important. Find tips on putting together an evacuation kit here: https://www.readyforwildfire.org/prepare-for-wildfire/get-set/emergency-supply-kit/

If you can, use fire-resistant building materials to harden your home. This will help mitigate any potential damage to your homes. @CAL_Fire has a great list of low-cost ways to harden your home. Find them here: 

http://www.readyforwildfire.org/wp-content/uploads/Low-cost-Retrofit-List-Updated.pdf

Avoid using outdoor equipment that can create sparks, like chainsaws or lawnmowers, during red-flag warnings. When traveling, make sure your vehicle does not have chains or other vehicle parts dragging on the ground that can cause a spark.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f4w74Q6G5Hk

When camping or just enjoying California‚Äôs beautiful wilderness and parks, always be sure to properly dispose of matches, cigarettes or any type of open flame. Please be especially careful when using campfires or grills.
https://www.readyforwildfire.org/prevent-wildfire/campfire-safety/

More than 90% of wildfires in California are traced back to humans, largely through unintentional errors. Check with local authorities regarding any burn bans before heading outdoors. Weather conditions can make a variety of tasks and activities dangerous.https://www.readyforwildfire.org/prevent-wildfire/
